section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: This hands-on programming section explores the essentials of variables and data types in Python, focusing on declaration, manipulation, and practical application through coding exercises to build foundational programming skills.
learning_objectives: Students will be able to declare and assign variables using proper Python syntax
Students will be able to identify and utilize primitive data types including integers, floats, strings, and booleans
Students will be able to perform basic operations and type conversions on variables
Students will be able to debug common errors related to variable naming and data types

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create variables, assign initial values, and understand Python's dynamic typing by writing simple assignment statements
key_topics: Variable naming rules using lowercase letters and underscores
The assignment operator (=) and multiple assignments

exercises.exercise_instructions: Write a Python script that declares three variables: user_name as a string with your name, user_age as an integer with your age, and is_student as a boolean True, then print each variable's value
Create a script that assigns the same value 'Python' to three variables (lang1, lang2, lang3) in one line, then reassign lang2 to 'Java' and print all three

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to apply arithmetic operations on integers and floats, handling results with mixed types
key_topics: Integer literals and their range in Python
Addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division operators

exercises.exercise_instructions: Declare variables x as 10 (int) and y as 3.5 (float), then compute and print the sum, product, and quotient of x and y
Write a script with celsius as 25.5 (float), convert to fahrenheit using the formula (celsius * 9/5) + 32, assign to fahrenheit variable, and print both values

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to concatenate strings and evaluate boolean conditions to control simple logic flows
key_topics: Boolean values and comparison operators like == and >

exercises.exercise_instructions: Declare first_name as 'John' and last_name as 'Doe', concatenate them with a space into full_name, then print 'Hello, full_name'
Set age as 20 (int) and adult as age >= 18, then print adult as a boolean; repeat with age set to 16 and print the result

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to convert data types explicitly and verify variable types to avoid runtime errors
key_topics: Built-in functions like int(), float(), str(), and bool()
The type() function for inspecting data types

exercises.exercise_instructions: Declare num_str as '42', convert it to an integer using int(), assign to num_int, then print type(num_int) and perform num_int + 8
Create variables of different types: a=5, b=3.14, c='hello', d=True; use type() to print each type and convert c to float if possible, handling any error with a comment
